Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: AAdvances in the Design of Approximation Algorithms for Optimization Problems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
For most applications in which optimization algorithms are used in industry, and in particular problems from logistics, supply-chain management, routing, and network design, the computational problems are intractable -- there are severe restrictions on the size of input data that can be quickly and reliably solved to optimality. We will focus on the development of new algorithmic techniques in the design of algorithms to produce good solutions for these critical problems. The theoretical foundation of these algorithms is that they possess a performance guarantee that assures that the solutions computed are nearly optimal; for example, the project aims to devise efficient algorithms to find solutions for which the cost is no more than a specified percentage more than the minimum possible. The project also considers stochastic optimization problems, where the input consists of a probability distribution over inputs, thereby giving rise to even more difficult problems than if the input is known with certainty. We will focus on problem formulations and approaches that allow us to model the requisite probability distributions using historical data archives.

This project aims to provide algorithms with strong guarantees for a number of theoretical models including the capacitated facility location problem, which arises in many industrial contexts from the positioning of warehouses in a distribution network to the choice of hub placements in high-bandwidth networks; the generalized assignment problem, which has a range of workload-balancing applications in heterogeneous environments; the bottleneck asymmetric traveling salesman problem (TSP), which arises in scheduling of chemical processing plants (known technically as a no-wait flowshop scheduling environment), as well as the more often studied minimum-sum variant; and several stochastic optimization models including one arising from the adaptive routing of medical transport planes.

Finding good approaches to gain new efficiencies in logistical planning is an issue that is important for the overall US economy, and this is a long-term goal of this project. Our viewpoint is that the study of simplified models will yield algorithmic paradigms that can be applied to realistic settings with industry-scale data and complexities. The insight needed to prove strong theorems about the quality of the solutions found translates into algorithmic principles, which in turn leads to algorithms that work well on the problems that industry needs to solve. By training graduate students in this area, this project will also contribute to the important effort to ensure that the US workforce has sufficient expertise to meet the technological challenges of the coming century in the area of logistics support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The design and analysis of approximation algorithms for fundamental discrete optimization problems has been one of the most fruitful lines of investigation within theoretical computer science over the past twenty years.  Discrete optimization problems arise in a myriad of application settings, for example, being at the core of virtually every aspect of logistics management – including routing, network design, and inventory management. Another setting in which new optimization problems are becoming critical is the emerging area of computational sustainability, with problems stemming from as disparate domains as the management of land reserves to the operation of a bike-sharing system.

Scientific Merit - We have designed improved algorithms for many of the most basic optimization models as well as several for which improvements are at the core of many central logistical supply-chain problems. The most notable advance obtained by this project is the discovery of a simple extension to one of the most well-studied algorithms, Christofides' algorithm for the Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP). In the traveling salesman problem, we are given a set of locations to visit, and we wish to find the cheapest route to start a given location, visit all of the specified places, and then return home along the most efficient route. Our work focuses on a slight variant of this problem, in which the specified ending location is not the same as the starting location. One of the key elements in Christofides' algorithm is the computing of a cheap way to connect up all of the locations to visit, without them necessarily forming a particular path - this is formally called a minimum spanning tree computation - for which efficient algorithms have been known for decades. Our innovation shows how one can use a common tool known as linear programming to compute a portfolio of good spanning trees, rather than the cheapest, and then use each of these in turn within Christofides' algorithm. Furthermore, we show that the resulting algorithm has a provable performance benefit, guaranteeing a better relative error with respect to the minimum cost routing for the salesman. In doing so, we provide the first such improvement in decades, and this is viewed as a fundamental question in the design of approximation algorithms.

The management of inventory is at the heart of many retail businesses, and with the advent of entities like Amazon, occur on a scale that was heretofore beyond the ability to manage algorithmically. We consider a number of inventory management problems, and model them as discrete optimization problems, and design approximation algorithms for them. This has given rise to the first constant-factor approximation algorithms for many of the most important subclasses of the submodular joint replishment problem, the assortment optimization problem, and a number of capacitated covering problems including one particularly important example known the capacitated lot-sizing problem. In closely related work, we have given new algorithms (based on new linear programming relaxations) for a broad class of scheduling problems, so that it is now possible to efficiently schedule a machine where the jobs arrive over time, and the aim is to optimize any non-decreasing sum of (any) non-decreasing function of their completion times.

We have also studied a number of optimization problems in the domain of comptutational sustainability. Here we are interested in algorithmic questions with the aim of addressing issues that confront the public in maintaining our natural resources. In this domain, there are two distinct threads of research in this project.
